bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 19, 1947

div1.p: Hench discusses the notes on Kean's yellow fever chart. He requests that Kean look over the letters written to Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 19, 1947
div1.opener:
February 19, 1947
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, North West
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for returning my interview with
the Reeds and for your comments thereon. I enclose some data
which I think will interest you. They include photostatic
copies of your own fever chart with the hand-written notes of
your case undoubtedly in Lambert's handwriting. His hand-
writing hasn't changed much through the years. It was inter-
esting to me to note what close care he gave to his patients.
You will see that he made notes throughout the night as well
as the day and must have been “Johnny on the spot” twenty-
four hours at a time. I enclose two letters written to
Doctor Ames by a Doctor Berry and a letter which Doctor Berry
wrote to the Editor of the Journal of the American Medical
Association. You will see that Ames never did answer pre-
cisely Doctor Berry's question as to how Ames got his yellow
fever. He apparently allowed Doctor Berry to continue to
think that he (Ames) might have gotten his yellow fever ex-
perimentally, but at least in this correspondence Berry was
never sure. I should appreciate greatly whatever comments you
wish to write about these letters, either on the back or on a
separate sheet. Please do so at your leisure and return them
at your convenience.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
